clinical_study.brief_title: RBC Lifespan Measurement in Diabetic Children
clinical_study.official_title: Red Blood Cell Lifespan Measurement in Diabetic Children

brief_summary.textblock: HbA1c, a measure of mean blood glucose over the lifespan of a red blood cell (RBC), is a marker of increasing importance both for assessing glycemic control in children with known diabetes and for the diagnosis of diabetes in children. HbA1c has demonstrated poor reliability in diagnosis and management of pediatric diabetes and the most plausible reason for this unreliability is that the reference ranges of HbA1c were established based on 120-day RBC lifespan observed in adults, without considering the RBC lifespan difference between children and adults. The proposed studies will for the first time determine RBC lifespan in diabetic children

primary_outcome.measure: Measurement of RBC survival in diabetic children using biotin-labeled RBCs
primary_outcome.description: the lifespan of red blood cells in children with diabetes

arm_group.arm_group_label: Biotin labeled RBCs in 4-10 year old diabetes children

arm_group.arm_group_label: Biotin labeled RBCs in 10-18 year old diabetes children
arm_group.description: Biotin labeled autologous red blood cells will be transfused to the subjects

intervention.description: Autologous red blood cells are biotin labeled and transfused to the subjects. Survival of these red blood cells is tracked through examination of blood samples until no biotin-labeled red blood cells is detectable.
